channel.title: Encryption on jrobb.org
channel.description: Recent content in Encryption on jrobb.org

item.title: Proton Pass: A Guide to Secure Password Management
item.description: Proton Pass: A Guide to Secure Password Management In a digital world where security breaches are increasingly common, using a password manager is no longer just an option but a necessity. In this guide, we delve into Proton Pass, Proton’s answer to secure password management, offering you step-by-step instructions on setup, usage, and integration. For a broader look at Proton’s privacy-focused services, check out my previous post on Proton’s encrypted offerings.

item.title: Proton Mail and other Services
item.description: Exploring Proton and Their Suite of Privacy-Focused Services In an age where digital privacy is increasingly under threat, Proton has emerged as a beacon for those seeking secure communication and data protection. Starting with Proton Mail, the company has expanded its offerings to include a variety of tools designed to keep your digital life private and secure. Proton Mail: The Heart of Proton’s Services Advantages of Encrypted Communication Proton Mail is renowned for its end-to-end encryption, ensuring that your email content is secure from the moment it leaves your device until it reaches the recipient.

item.title: Bitmessage
item.description: Lately I’ve started finding Bitmessage interesting again. I used it a little early on, but haven’t in a year or so. After recovering my address, I’ve been back on the network and I’m remembering that I really like the idea of it–mostly the simplicity! Compared to GPG, this is no contest that almost anyone could use this. Some people feel that GPG is damn near unusable, and while I don’t really agree, according to the guy in that talk I (and probably you) are considered the “technological elite.

item.title: SSH box
item.description: Work has been very crazy for the past few weeks, so I haven’t had much of a chance to update this. Unfortunately I haven’t even had a chance to even play Minecraft. Although I did manage to log in and convert my local worlds to the new format, but that’s about the extent of it. So a while back I received an eeePC 900a from a friend who owed me $25.

item.title: set up ssh encrypted socks tunnel
item.description: So I had started this a long time ago, and forgotten all about it as I really didn’t have a use for it. Now that I have the ability to tether, and I have my eeePC working again, combined with attending LUGs–now I have the use for a secure tunnel. In case you aren’t aware (I wasn’t), passwords and logins are sent in PLAIN TEXT–yes, I said plain text. Nuts, huh?
